about,"

About the Interactive Diversity Map

In this tool, we use the USA Today Diversity Index developed by Meyer and McIntosh (1999). This is a probability-based index to assess the amount of difference in a population along one particular dimension. The index has a range from 0 to 1 representing the probability that two people chosen at random from the population will differ along a chosen dimension. A value of zero would apply to a population in which everyone was the same. A value of one would apply to a population in which each person was different from every other person in that dimension.
While the original index was created to measure ethnic diversity, diversity can come in many forms. This tool shows diversity in Boston as measured by
column2: Place of Birth, Language Spoken at Home, Age, Household Income, and Educational Attainment in addition to Race and Ethnicity.&nbsp

column1: For example, consider a measurement of diversity based on graduation from high school or not. In this case, a maximally diverse population would consist of exactly half high school graduates and half non-high school graduates. The probability of two people chosen at random from the population being different along the high school graduation dimension would be 50 percent and therefore the diversity index would by 0.50. A less diverse population would consist of 70 high school graduates for every 30 non-high school graduates. In this case, the probability of two people chosen at random being different along the high school graduation dimension would be 42 percent and the diversity index would by 0.421. A population in which the proportions were switched (30 high school graduates for every 70 non-high school graduates) would have the same diversity index score of 0.42 because the probability of two randomly chosen people being different along this same dimension would still be 42 percent

However, the diversity of a given population depends heavily on how diversity is defined. Going back to our earlier example of using educational attainment, suppose we want to measure not only high school graduates and non-high school graduates but also those who may have gone on to continue their education. Now using three categories (non-high school graduates, highschool graduates with less than a Bachelor&rsquo
column2: s degree, and those with a Bachelor&rsquo
column3: s degree or higher) as a measure of diversity, a maximally diverse population would include an equal number of individuals within each category, i.e. 33 people with no high school diploma, 33 with a high school diploma or equivalent, and 34 with a bachelor&rsquo
column4: s or higher with a resulting diversity index of approximately 0.67.&nbsp

column1: Previously, a population of 50 non high school graduates and 50 high school graduates can be
column2: considered to be more diverse than the population of 30 non high school graduates and 70 high school graduates. Suppose that of the high school graduates, exactly half of each population went on to obtain a bachelor&rsquo
column3: s degree or more advanced degree. If we then recalculate the diversity index with the three-category definition, the second population (30 non-high school graduates
column4: 35 high school graduates without a Bachelor&rsquo
column7: s degree or higher, with a score of 0.665) is now more diverse than the first population (50 non-high school graduates
column8: 25 high school graduates without a Bachelor&rsquo
column11: s degree or higher, with a score of 0.625) since it more closely resembles what has been determined as maximally diverse by having a more equal distribution among the defined categories.&nbsp

column1: The U.S. Census provides an explanation using different groupings and categorical formations using specifically race and ethnicity for a more thorough walk-through, which can be found here.
For each demographic subject highlighted in this tool (Race &
column2: Ethnicity, Region of Birth, Language Spoken at Home, Age, Household Income, and Educational Attainment), we provide various groupings and categorisations to use as a definition of diversity rather than supplying a single predetermined measure. Different groupings may be more or less relevant depending on the particular context.&nbsp

column1: We also provide different modes of comparisons. Within each tab there&rsquo
column2: s the option to compare visually with a map across census tracts in Boston, to compare across Boston&rsquo
column3: s neighborhoods and in relation to the City, and to compare Boston to a selection of comparable cities in the United States.&nbsp

Data is collected for all persons on their race and ethnicity.
The available options for race are:
• Black or African American
• American Indian and Alaska Native
• Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander
• Some other race
• Two or more races
The available options for ethnicity are:
• Hispanic or Latino
• Not Hispanic or Latino.
The available options for two or more races are:
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Black or African American &amp
• All other two race combinations
• Population of three races
• Population of four or more races

The options to categorize diversity for race and ethnicity in this tool are Race and Ethnicity (Hispanic as a separate category), Race with Hispanic Ethnicity Distinction, and Race with Detailed Multiracial Categories.
Race and Ethnicity (Hispanic as a separate category) uses the following categories:
• Non-HIspanic Black or African American
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Non-Hispanic American Indian and Alaska Native&nbsp
• Non-Hispanic Asian and Pacific Islnader
• Non-Hispanic Other Race
• Non-Hispanic two or more races
• Hispanic or Latino
This option follows the common five-category ethnoracial classification with multiracial individuals and individuals classified as some other race
Race with Hispanic Ethnicity Distinction uses the following categories:
• Non-Hispanic Black or African American
• Non-Hispanic American Indian and Alaska Native
• Non-Hispanic Asian and Pacific Islander
• Non-Hispanic Other Race
• Non-Hispanic two or more races
• Hispanic American Indian and Alaska Native
• Hispanic Asian or Pacific Islander
• Hispanic Other Race
• Hispanic two or more races

This option preserves the common racial classification but distributes Hispanic ethnicity among the available races. Including racial classifications within the Hispanic ethnicity places emphasis on the intersectionality between race and ethnicity.
Race with Detailed Multiracial Categories
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Black or African American&nbsp
• American Indian and Alaska Native
• Asian or Pacific Islander
• Some other single race
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Black or African American &amp

This option focuses on the differences and diversity within the multiracial census category. As a note, data for multiracial persons does not include an ethnicity dimension, so Hispanic or Latino persons are distributed along their racial identities.

lang,

Language Spoken at Home
Data is collected for persons aged 5 years and older on the primary spoken language at home. The available options are:
• Speak only English
• French, Haitian, or Cajun
• German or other West Germanic languages
• Russian, Polish, or other Slavic languages
• Other Indo-European languages
• Chinese (incl. Mandarin, Cantonese)
• Other Asian and Pacific Island languages
• Other and unspecified languages

The options to categorize diversity for languages spoken at home in this tool are All 10 Languages with available data, Primarily speaks English at home/Does not primarily speak English at home, and Top 5 Languages in Boston with available data.

All 10 Languages with available data includes all specified and/or named languages (for example Korean as opposed to Other Asian and Pacific Island languages). This option provides more specificity in describing the character of multilingual households in Boston while remaining as inclusive as possible.

Primarily speaks English at home/Does not primarily speak English at home compares those who speak only English at home to those who may speak English and another language or only another language at home. Since English has the plurality in the city and is also a major lingua franca in the United States, this option considers the division between the most common language and other languages in which thousands of Americans speak and communicate on a daily basis.
Top 5 Languages in Boston with available data includes the languages spoken with higher frequency in Boston: English
column5: and Vietnamese. This option focuses on the languages that are more commonly spoken in Boston than in other parts of the country, such as Vietnamese or Haitian Creole. To note, other prominent languages in Boston such as Portuguese and Kabuverdianu (Cape Verdean Creole) are not specifically enumerated in the American Community Survey.

column1: Further information about Boston&rsquo
column2: s threshold languages or language access can be found at the Mayor'
column3: s Language and Communication Access Department. The department does work with an equity-focused lens which includes advocating for translation services in Boston&rsquo

• Nursery to 4th grade,
• 5th and 6th grade,
• 7th and 8th grade,
• 12th grade, no diploma,
• High school graduate (includes equivalency),
• Some college, less than 1 year,
• Some college, 1 or more years, no degree,
• Professional school degree, and
The options to categorize diversity for educational attainment in this tool are 5 Levels of Educational Attainment, Less than High School/High School or Higher, and Less than a Bachelor&rsquo
5 Levels of Educational Attainment considers the following levels:
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Less than high school,&nbsp
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">High School/GED or equivalent,&nbsp
Less than High School/High School or Higher compares those who did not graduate high school or obtain a GED and those who completed high school and/or continued their formal education.
<span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial""><strong><em>Less than a Bachelor&rsquo
column3: s Degree or higher compares those who have formal schooling less than a Bachelor&rsquo
column4: s Degree and those who obtained a Bachelor&rsquo
column5: s Degree or a more advanced degree.

column1: hh,<h2><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Data are collected for all households on their household income in the last 12 months in 2021 inflation-adjusted dollars. The available options are:&nbsp
• $150,000 to $199,999, and
• $200,000 or more.
The options to categorize diversity for household income in this tool are 6 Income Brackets, Below/Above Boston&rsquo
column2: s Median Household Income, and 3 Income Brackets.

column1: 6 Income Brackets separates households into the following bins:
• $100,000 to $124,999, and
• $125,000 or more

column2: s Median Household Income splits the households by being above or below Boston&rsquo
column3: s median household income of $81,744<sup>1</sup> in 2021. However, the available census options limit precision so the tool uses $75,000 as the median household income.&nbsp

column1: 3 Income Brackets separates households into the following categories:
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Low-income households (Less than $50,000),&nbsp
• Middle-income households (Between $50,000 and less than $125,000), and
• High-income households ($125,000 or more).
These categories were chosen to represent a third of all households, i.e. there is an even split between the three categories at the city level.
1 Boston in Context 2023, BPDA Research Division

Data is collected for all persons on place of birth and nativity status. There are too many available options for this particular category to list, but greater specificity will be given in the following descriptions.
The options to categorize diversity for region of birth in this tool are By Nativity, By U.S. Region, By Boston&rsquo
column2: s Top 10 Countries of Birth, and By the United States&rsquo
column3: Top 10 Countries of Birth.

column1: By Nativity splits the population by whether an individual is considered Native-born or Foreign-born. Native-born can be defined as being born in the United States, Puerto Rico, or U.S. territories or being born abroad of American parents.
By U.S. Region expands upon the earlier category by specifying in which region of the United States the individual was born. In particular, the regions are defined as follows:
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Born in state of residence
• Northeast (Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts*, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, and Vermont)

<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Midwest (Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota and Wisconsin)

<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">South (Alabama, Arkansas, Delaware, District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia and West Virginia)

<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">West (Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming)
<li style=""list-style-type:disc""><span style=""color:#003d50""><span style=""font-size:11pt""><span style=""font-family:Arial"">Born in U.S. territory or abroad of American parents

*For all of Boston, the state of residence is Massachusetts. For the comparable city calculations, the state of residence category is the state in which that particular city is located and people born in MA are grouped in the Northeast region. E.g. In San Francisco, people born in California are in their own group under &lsquo

column1:
age,

Data are collected for all persons.
The options to categorize diversity for age in this tool are By Broad Age Brackets, By adulthood status, and By Decade.
By Broad Age Brackets separates people into the following bins:
• 35 to 59, and
• 60 and over.
These bins roughly correspond to various stages of life (child, young adult, adult, and senior citizen).
By adulthood status separates people based on whether or not they are under 18 or 18 and older.
By Decade separates people into 10-year brackets (0-9 years old, 10-19 years old, etc.).
For more information about young adults or older adults, SPARK Boston and the Age Strong Commission provide various resources and equity-focused work for age-specific populations.
